bug.author: emmbertelen
bug.description:
<denchmark-h:h2>üêõ Bug</denchmark-h>
I work in JupyterLab. I am trying to train with custom data. I have the exact same copy of my directory structure that <denchmark-link:https://github.com/ultralytics/yolov3/wiki/Train-Custom-Data>Train Custom Data</denchmark-link> showed with Coco. The training stops with 'No labels found' after 'Caching labels'. <denchmark-link:https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9340045/78763567-970c5300-7985-11ea-8684-d549642a4dd7.png></denchmark-link>
Any idea on this? Thanks.

comments.comment: I run into the same error like you emmbertelen, but I work on linux, not jupyter.
I also got the same error.

I resolved it. Image path should be <denchmark-code>./coco/images/train100.jgp' not ../coco/images/train100.jgp' </denchmark-code>
remove one '.' from class files.
but you put the coco folder outside of yolo folder, right?

but you put the coco folder outside of yolo folder, right?
Inside the yolo folder where train.py exists.
all paths are relative to the yolov3 folder. In the tutorials the coco folder is alongside the yolov3 folder, not inside it.

<denchmark-link:https://github.com/glenn-jocher>@glenn-jocher</denchmark-link> I also tried with coco. I left everything as it is in the tutorial. I tried with the image set of data/coco1cls.txt, and coco alongside with yolo. Only created a coco1.names file with one class in it, and a coco1cls.data file: <denchmark-link:https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9340045/78815141-1757a600-79d0-11ea-9421-4849c02114e1.png></denchmark-link>
And the training died just like before: <denchmark-link:https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9340045/78815258-4c63f880-79d0-11ea-98da-edfed9677599.png></denchmark-link>

<denchmark-link:https://github.com/emmbertelen>@emmbertelen</denchmark-link> I updated the error message to show you exactly where it is looking in <denchmark-link:https://github.com/ultralytics/yolov3/commit/f54d28ba637a8ec7259bc51d7f3f956b1b382871>f54d28b</denchmark-link>
If you git pull and try again it will show you the search folder. You should use the directory structure established in the tutorial and go from there.

For example, if I rename my coco folder and try to train, I see this. This path is relative to the yolov3 folder. Namespace(accumulate=4, adam=False, batch_size=16, bucket='', cache_images=False, cfg='cfg/yolov3-spp.cfg', data='data/coco16.data', device='', epochs=300, evolve=False, img_size=[416], multi_scale=False, name='', nosave=False, notest=False, rect=False, resume=False, single_cls=False, weights='weights/yolov3-spp-ultralytics.pt') Using CPU
Run 'tensorboard --logdir=runs' to view tensorboard at http://localhost:6006/ Model Summary: 225 layers, 6.29987e+07 parameters, 6.29987e+07 gradients Caching labels: 100%|‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà| 16/16 [00:00<00:00, 86928.58it/s] Traceback (most recent call last): File "/Users/glennjocher/PycharmProjects/yolov3/train.py", line 425, in <module> train() # train normally File "/Users/glennjocher/PycharmProjects/yolov3/train.py", line 178, in train single_cls=opt.single_cls) File "/Users/glennjocher/PycharmProjects/yolov3/utils/datasets.py", line 382, in __init__ assert nf > 0, 'No labels found in %s. See %s' % (os.path.dirname(file) + os.sep, help_url) AssertionError: No labels found in ../coco/labels/train2017/. See https://github.com/ultralytics/yolov3/wiki/Train-Custom-Data

<denchmark-link:https://github.com/glenn-jocher>@glenn-jocher</denchmark-link> Thank you very much for your help, it made me identify the problem. My "parent" directory, where I stored my custom images and labels was: 'tower_images'. And look at this: datasets.py replaced every "images" in the path. Im not sure if it is a bug, but this is one of the most hilarious thing that was blocking me for 2 days... Btw Im very thankful for your work and for this yolo implenetation, it really inspires me. <denchmark-link:https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9340045/78881718-7b717d00-7a57-11ea-960e-34b88eafa28d.png></denchmark-link>
So after all, I renamed my dataset's directory, and now it trains.
<denchmark-link:https://github.com/emmbertelen>@emmbertelen</denchmark-link> ah great! No this is not a bug, it searches for /labels/ next to an /images/ folder.
